U got one cent from that machine
Definately a different take on it and it definately works, I'm restoring a similar one myself in a slight Dr Pepper theme. While not identical based on the one I have I think your missing a couple of parts, there should be a Silicone gasket at the base of the globe which should stop it moving about when the Lids screwed down, the mechanisim is probably missing a restrictor piece as they come new with instructions to remove it for those just wanting free vend. You can control the amount by adjusting the metal plate on the wheel, just loosen the 3 screws and drop a gumball in and slide it to where it meets the ball and go back about a mm or two, that should set it to one ball per turn (or however many you want it set to based on position), hope it helps.

once you get to the point where you have the first layer of the color layers, you might like trying to use the sponge brushes to do the ombre  part, put one color on one half of the brush and the other color on the other half, line them up close together, then *TAPTAPTAPTAPTAPTAPTAPTAPTAPTAP* your way to quick pretty ombre (bonus: do a swipe along the line with the same sponge brush at the end to get rid of the bumps that might come up from the technique so it looks more like a paintbrush instead, idk how hard that part might be though)

Romans 3:23 states: "For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God;". We are all sinners, that have committed at least one sin in our lives, which earns us an eternal punishment in Hell. Revelation states 21:8 "But the fearful, and unbelieving, and the abominable, and murderers, and whoremongers, and sorcerers, and idolaters, and all liars, shall have their part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone: which is the second death.". God sent his Son, Jesus, to Earth as a perfect sinless sacrifice. To take on all the sins of the world; both past, present, and future sins. Shedding his blood on the cross as a blood atonement for all sins. After dying on the cross, he rose from the dead on the 3rd day and rose to Heaven. To show life after death. To show everlasting life through Jesus's sacrifice. John 14:6 states: "Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me.". Romans 10:13 states "For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.".      Eternal life in heaven is just one prayer away. All you have to do is believe that Jesus Christ, the Son of God, died on the cross for your sins. As an atonement for your sins. And rose from the grave on the 3rd day. Ask Jesus to save you of your sins and give you eternal life in Heaven. Salvation is a free and everlasting gift from God. Please don't let pride drag you into eternal punishment in Hell, but ask Jesus to give you eternal life in Heaven. If you're getting a strong feeling of resistance while reading this, it's because Satan doesn't want you to get saved. He wants you to resist, and think it's not real. He wants you in Hell for all eternity with him. Hell is not a fun place, like worldly people like to imagine. It's everlasting torture with no relief. I'm only taking the time to text this, because I want to get the message out. There are so many distractions in life keeping people from witnessing to other people. Keeping you from thinking about salvation. Keeping you from thinking about life after death. Please, ask Jesus into your hearts to save you of your sins and cleanse you from all unrighteous. Ask him for a place in Heaven, and he will save you from eternal damnation in Hell.

This is so cute. I've always wanted to get a gumball machine and basically use it as a piggy bank. Lol.   But my girl. I'm by no means a professional but let me give you some tips I learned from painting super random crap my whole life. Painting Glass with Something not Meant to Paint Glass: you really want to go with acrylics here. *Very* lightly scuff up the glass with as fine of sand paper you can get your hands on. You don't need it all scratched to hell, but just light enough to give the paint something to hug. Also only scuff up where you want your art to be. You can do this by lightly tracing/sketching your art with a wet watercolor pencil or fine no pasca and scuffing up the glass inside your lines. wipe it clean with alcohol. You super want to make sure there are zero oils from your hands on the glass and no dust from scuffing the glass. Then add your paint. Use thin layers to minimize brush strokes. Once your first layer is dry, *gently* rub your work with a dry paper towel! I've found that paper towels are ever so slightly abrasive and have helped to minimize brush strokes in glass, porcelain and resin(bjdsâ™¥ï¸) really well. So between each layer of paint, give it a healthy but gentle rub down with the paper towel. When using a brush you won't/shouldn't need to seal between layers. Paper towel sanding will work with your clear coat too: use very very thin layers and rub it down *while dry* between layers. You don't want to touch wet sealant with a paper towel, you WILL cry. Try to not get too much sealant outside of your drawing unless you are using a spray (you won't need to worry about brush strokes with a spray on sealant so you won't need to rub down with a towel unless you get a little heavy handed and end up with drips.) If you spray the whole glass, you won't need to rub it down. If you only spray the paintings, just rub down the edges really well to help blend them out. Same with a brush on sealant: scrub the edges with a dry paper towel to help blend them out. You already seem to have done a fantastic job cleaning up the edges, I just left that bit for anyone else who wants to paint glass too :3

Nelson looks like he farted in church..  Hey!  . . . . Did you know that there is someone who loves you unconditionally? Someone who loves you more than anyone on Earth? Well, he does. Jesus does. He loves *YOU* so much that he came while you were a sinner - not after you cleaned up your act - and died for you. He shed his blood for you, becoming the perfect sacrifice for all of time. He rose on the third day, ensuring victory over death, hell and the grave. He told the devil that he was defeated _TO HIS FACE_ and that is why there is so much evil raging in this world right now. Satan wants to steal as many people as he can from God, trapping them in eternal damnation. BUT - Jesus made a way when there was no way.   All you have to do to gain eternal life is: 1) Believe that Jesus came and died for you. 2) Accept him as your savior and confess out loud that he is your Savior. 3) Cast away the things of the world and live strictly for God. There is nothing that you could do that would separate you from the love of the Heavenly father... except live a life of sin. Sin in the only thing thing that keeps us from God because he, like Heaven, is perfect and sin is not welcome in his kingdom. Do you know what you're escaping when you commit to Jesus? You're escaping the eternal torment that you deserve as a sinner, but Jesus died as the perfect, sacrifice to take the burdens of your sins for you. You are escaping the constant reminders of what you did on Earth that you always put before seeking God. The torment.. the agony.. it goes on forever, night and day with no end and not rest. Think of sin like stains on your clothes. When we sin, a stain appears, but when you ask Jesus to forgive you, he switches clothes with you, so when you are looked at by God, all he sees is a spotless robe, on his beloved child.   How do you repent? Easy! You 1) Confess that you're a sinner, and because of that you need Jesus, and His Holy Spirit to guide you daily. 2) Turn away from sin and turn to the word of God. The unchanging, absolute truth that is basically a road-map to the King of Kings. Put your trust in the blood of Christ and you will be saved. Time is running short, you guys. The rapture is so close. Make the choice today... tomorrow is not guaranteed..

omg, paint pen on glass has become my primary medium & now you're doing it too!!! im so excited for you!! things ive learned:   1. oil-based paint pens are most durable 2. wear gloves to keep your fingy prints off the glass 3. denatured alcohol will take off your mistakes (dark colors need denatured alcohol AND scraping) 4. it's so easy to scrape your paint on the second coat. i like to flood my pens a lil so i dont need to press hard, but this obviously has risks  anywho, it looks great and im so proud of you! nice job

i would love to see some of your characters done in aquarell. but not modern ig-watercolor (with using white paint or pens) but old-timey aquarell (leaving space or using more water to lighten colors, layering, lifting up color etc.). i understand that it can be really hard, when you're used to acryl or poscas, but i think someone like you could master that too! i would recommend to use good paper and high quality brushes and paint like schmincke or daniel smith.   i would also love to see you try some indi paint-brands from etsy for example.

12:44 these are 8 bagsğŸ˜‚
I really love this design!ğŸ˜ You really need to get a high quality airbrush kit for such projects. It would make doing gradients on even awkward shaped surfaces SO much easier! (Not to mention faster)  I actually found one which in addition to the normal metal paint holding tank...actually has multiple PLASTIC paint holding tanks for the airbrush. Which allows you to just turn the sprayer upside down, remove the paint holder & put on another...allowing you to quickly & EASILY change colors! Which fixes one of the drawbacks of using an airbrush for some projects. Having multiple tanks can also help when you are making custom colors for a project. Or another option for custom mixed colors is you can mix your colors in resealable little glass or plastic jars/pots & use a dropper to put it in the airbrush as needed...or you can buy squeeze bottles like the paint comes in for long term storage. I use both methods when I either have a LOT of space to cover or if I am doing multiple art pieces over several days with the same colors.  There are just SO MANY colors, finishes, additives, etc for use in airbrushes now itâ€™s unreal. I think it would be awesome to see you use one.â¤ï¸

Do not use an apostrophe in verbs. Apostrophes sometimes show up in verbs that end in -s, such as marks, *sees* , or finds." This is what happens when I try to be big brain. I mess up.

U could have used acrylic paint on the glass, and it wouldn't lift the paint with a second layer. If you donâ€™t know what I mean then here is an explanation: The percentage of people who skip ads heavily impacts YouTubers' revenue as YouTube does not count skipped ads as a view. Advertisers don't pay for skipped ads, and therefore creators do not get paid for viewers who skip ads. If a YouTuber has an audience made of people who always skip ads, they won't earn as much.

YOU NEED TO DO ANOTHER MAKING YOUR SQUISHIES INTO A DESSERTTT
Gesso is very similar to white acrylic paint, only thinner. It dries hard, making the surface more stiff. Gesso prepares (or "primes") the surface for painting, making the surface slightly textured and ready to accept acrylic paint. Without gesso, the paint would soak into the weave of the canvas. - Google   I know you've been having some suspicions about gesso, so hopefully, this will clear things up.

How bubble gum was created: There once was a man who worked in a gum factory not bubble gum just regular gum and one day he was very bored so he decided to experiment with a a few ingredients and the colour he used was rose    And after he mixed everything he realized it was similar to gum but it made bubbles thats how it was created. Pink is a bubble gum color bc when it was first created color used was rose and rose is  pretty much pink.

Hey bekah
Okay I have to comment on the "price" thing at the end as I grew up with a vintage restored one. There's supposed a plate that goes into the circular hole in the facing. Each plate has a sized slot to only accept certain denominations of coin before it lets the gear turn. In some of the newer machines, there's even double or triple slots to accept 50 or 75 cents. Without the plate, the gear can be turned freely, letting you just take the gum.

i work in a thrift store and is is one of my hates people giving us dirty stuff and expecting us to sell it and we then have to clean it best we can and hope it'll sell but some things are just too far gone and has to be trashed. like the donations are appreciated but i don't think many people would want to buy dirty stuff, it's a time waster having to go though dirty stuff to find something sellable when other stuff could be being done, plus it makes the store look bad and gives thrift stores a bad name and look that they are dirty places  that sell dead people's random stuff. urm nope not any more here in the uk anyway most of them are like normal stores at times and even sell new stock that's been bought in (usually at Christmas), have stuff out according to season, have designer sections. And there's a lot of rules and regulations now of what we can and can't sell mainly due to safety but of course like anything common sense is appreciated.

Hey Moriah, I don't know if you're ever going to see this, but I wanted to thank you: This past year, my girlfriend and best friend was diagnosed with cancer, so through this terrible pandemic we have been going for blood work and chemotherapy and doing our best to stay safe and positive. And one way that we've been able to stay positive is by watching your videos.  It is a long drive to get to her doctors and a lot of waiting is involved, and over the course of this year I have shown her every single one of your videos starting from the beginning, (the WAY beginning), and it never fails to put a smile on her face and make her laugh. You have no idea how much it means to me to  able to do that.  Literally, even when we are stuck in line at the drive-thru at Starbucks, she always turns to me and goes "Moriah?" with this excited smile and it makes me so happy.  You do that, just by being you doing what you love, and reaching me through that passion, so now I'm able to share that with her.  Anyway, I will stop this before it becomes a novel, but I wanted to thank you so much for what you do, how you conduct yourself, and the positive tone of your videos. (I'm not saying you can't be a real person and have down feelings we all do, but) I really appreciate that you, by default, seem to just be a genuinely positive and kind person, it translates through your videos.  Thank you for all you do, much love, Tessa
